1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration process at the Bronco facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 

1.3.3 Sulfur Dioxide

The sulfur dioxide process at the Bronco facility is an integral part of overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that these areas and associated injection processes are maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Bronco is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of exposure to sulfur dioxide.

Our personnel also monitor the sulfur dioxide fumigation process and keep an active log of all associated procedures and transactions. In addition, the process is checked frequently by the outside contractor that supplies the SO2 cylinders. The contractor also assists in performing the annual mechanical integrity review of our process equipment. 

1.4 Five Year Accident History

Bronco Wine Company has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.

The operation is conducted outdoors. A bleed line is available during portable tank filling. A second bleed line is also available to purge residual sulfur dioxide within the transfer lines before hoses are disconnected. These bleed lines are connected to a scrubber system which is continuously fed water.  Since sulfur dioxide is soluble in the water (forming sulfurous acid), no emissions are produced. Clean water passes through the scrubber continuously, thus, the water discharged to drain doesn’t become over saturated with sulfur dioxide and a highly corrosive acid is not produced.

Sulfur dioxide from a one-ton cylinder is injected into the must line containing juice to inhibit fermentation.  The feed rate is controlled by a mass flow meter and metering pump. Sulfur dioxide is soluble in water and juice, so no emissions are produced. The quantity of sulfur dioxide added is determined by the wine maker. The metering pump is interlocked with the must pump such that sulfur dioxide is only added when the must pump is on.

Sulfur dioxide gas is also used to prevent the growth of harmful bacteria in full and empty barrels in the Barrel Room. Sulfur dioxide is injected from a 6 lb. dispenser into the head space of barrels before and after they are filled with wine for aging.

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia or sulfur dioxide in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

ture control.

The refrigeration cycle operates on the principle of the latent heat of vaporization and the transfer/absorption of heat that occurs as a result. The compressors provide high-temperature, high-pressure vapor as ammonia vapor is compressed. Next, the evaporative condensers remove the heat of compression generated when the ammonia vapor is compressed.
The result of evaporative condensing is a high-pressure liquid, which drains to the receiver and is made available for cooling via control valves to other parts of the system. As cooling is required in chillers or wine tank jackets, the liquid is metered and pumped from the suction accumulators. As the liquid ammonia passes through the cooling coils or chillers, it absorbs heat from the wine and subsequently expands and vaporizes as the pressure of the ammonia drops.

The resulting liquid/vapor mixture is returned from the chillers to the accumulators, where the liquid and vapor are separated to protect the compressors from liquid slugging. Ammonia vapor is returned to the compressors to repeat the cycle and accumulated liquid ammonia at the bottom of the vessel supplies the pumps.  

1.2.2 Sulfur Dioxide Process Description

Sulfur dioxide gas is added to wines and juices to prevent unwanted microbial activity. Sulfur dioxide is also used to protect the headspace (air space at the top of a vessel) of storage tanks and barrels.

Sulfur dioxide is transferred from one-ton cylinders to 1kg, 6 lb., 25 lb., and 100 lb. portable cylinders.  The portable cylinders are transported to the point of use for injection into fruit juice, pulp and/or skins to inhibit unwanted microbial activity.

No chemical reactions or special process temperatures need to be maintained. The process involves the simple transfer from a larger vessel to a smaller one. Facility maintenance mechanics regularly monitor process parameters, including pressure, temperature, and vessel levels for proper operation. Abnormal conditions may be corrected by mechanics when trained for the task and when safe to do so but are typically referred to the refrigeration contractor technician. A qualified ammonia refrigeration company provides service, design, and most regular preventive maintenance for the system.

All refrigeration system equipment, including jacketed wine tanks, chillers, compressors, condensers, and receivers is located outside.

System components are connected with steel piping approved for ammonia refrigeration service and the system includes numerous safety devices, detection systems, alarms, and control valves. Physical protective measures and emergency shower and eyewash stations are located as required to improve safety. Oil pots are provided at various pressure vessels for periodically draining accumulated refrigerant oil safely.

Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams (P&ID) provide a graphical description of the system. Written Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) describe the modes of operation, safety and health considerations, operating limits, and the safety systems and their functions. The ammonia refrigeration system is audited regularly for mechanical integrity and complies with industry standards and the applicable codes and regulations.

The ammonia refrigeration system at Bronco Wine Company is used for controlling fermentation, chilling wine (referred to as “cold stabilization”) and chilling grape juice. 
Juice and wine are stored in tanks. The typical tank is constructed of epoxy coated stainless steel and insulated with high density foam insulation. 1.2 Process Description

Bronco Wine Company, produces wines at its Stanislaus County facility in Ceres, California.
The plant entrance is located along Bystrum Road and the facility is bordered by E. Keyes Road to the north, Pike Road on the east, and E. Taylor on the south. The entrance lies approximately 2.5 miles East of S. Carpenter Road and about 3.2 miles directly Northeast of State Highway. The small town of Keyes is located East of the facility along Highway 99. The area is largely agricultural with a few residences in the area.

The facility maintains approximately 380 full time employees on site. The plant operates three (3) shifts five (5) days a week throughout the year, except during the grape harvest season, when operation extends to seven (7) days a week and additional employees are hired for the season.  

The plant is comprised of offices, production and laboratory buildings, loading docks, warehouses, parking, tank farms, and wastewater ponds. The facility is fenced along the entire perimeter and there is a security guard shack at the entrance.

The Emergency Evacuation Assembly Areas are located as required for potential evacuations.  Employees are trained and drill for alarm responses and evacuations annually.

1. Executive Summary

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
-California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program – Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
-Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) – Title 40 CFR §68
-California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
-Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a “living document”. As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Bronco Wine Company Ceres Facility (Bronco) has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1 Bronco Wine Company, Risk and Process Safety Management Program

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Bronco has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Process Name                       | Process Chemical               | Process Quantity(lbs.)
Ammonia Refrigeration       Anhydrous Ammonia          250,000
Sulfur Dioxide                          Sulfur Dioxide                           24,000

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.
